data.name: Armagnac
data.value: Armagnac is a brandy distilled in the Armagnac region in southwest France. It is traditionally distilled in column stills instead of pot stills unlike Cognac.

data.name: BarrelStrength
data.value: Cask strength (or barrel proof) is a term used to describe whiskey that is aged at its natural high alcohol level (usually 60-65%), instead of being diluted with water.

data.name: Cognac
data.value: Cognac is a French brandy named after the town of Cognac. Its production requires the beverage be twice distilled in copper pots and aged at least 2 years in French oak barrels.

data.name: Kirschwasser
data.value: Kirschwasser, or simply kirsch, is a clear German brandy made from double distilled cherries. The cherries are fermented whole, and are usually sour, which gives the beverage a distinct slightly bitter, instead of sweet, flavor.

data.name: RumOrigin
data.value: The origin of the term "rum" is not clear, with some theories including: it was British slang for "the best", it was taken from the Latin word for sugar "saccharum", or it was derived from the Romani word "rum" which meant strong or potent.

data.name: RumPirate
data.value: The association of rum with pirates came about after the British Royal Navy captured Jamaica in 1655. Rum soon became a naval ration and grew abundant on the high seas, eventually becoming the drink of choice among sailors.

data.name: RumPopularity
data.value: Estimates from before the American Revolution had each man, woman, or child in the American colonies drinking an average of 3 gallons (14L) of rum each year.

data.name: RyeWhiskey
data.value: American rye whiskey must be made with at least 51% rye by law. Canadian "rye" whiskey is called rye for historical reasons, but doesn't necessarily contain any rye at all.

data.name: ScotchShelfLife
data.value: An unopened bottle of Scotch can last 100 years or more, and once opened, Scotch is good to drink for many years while the bottle is still mostly full.

data.name: ScotchWhiskey
data.value: Scotch whisky, or simply scotch, is malt or grain whisky made in Scotland. Its production is specified by law, requiring it to be aged in oak for three years, have an alcohol content of at least 40%, and not contain artificial additives.

data.name: TastingGlass
data.value: The general, industry accepted glasses used for whisky tasting are the tulip shaped, short stemmed glasses such as a sherry glass or copita. Another popular glass is the Scottish "Glencairn whisky glass".

data.name: TennesseeVsBourbon
data.value: There is virtually no difference between Tennessee Whiskey and Bourbon, except that Tennessee Whiskey is filtered through charcoal before aging (also known as the "Lincoln County Process").

data.name: WhiskeyEvaporate
data.value: In whisky distilling the term "angel's share" describes the 2-4% of volume that is lost each year due to evaporation. The term "devil's cut" describes the small amount lost due to absorption by the wooden barrels.

data.name: WhiskeyWhite
data.value: When most whiskey and spirits are first made they are clear in color. The dark hues and colors are acquired from the wood used in the aging process.

data.name: WhiskeyWord
data.value: The word whisky comes from the Gaelic "uisge beatha" which translates literally to "water of life".
